Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Inferring Spatio-Temporal Variations in the Risk of Extreme Precipitation in the Western United States from Tree Ring Chronologies
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to understand extreme cold-season precipitation dynamics along the west coast of the United States through an analysis of the moisture anomalies recorded by tree-ring chronologies across the coast and interior of the western U.S. Winters with high total precipitation amounts in the coastal regions are marked by a small number of extreme storms that exhibit distinct spatial patterns of precipitation across the coast and further inland. Building from this observation, this research will seek to develop a novel application of dendroclimatic evidence to explore the following questions: a) how is extreme precipitation variability expressed in a network of tree-ring chronologies; b) can this information provide insight on the space-time variability of storm tracks that cause these extreme events; and c) how can the joint variability of extreme precipitation and storm tracks be modeled to develop consistent, multi-centennial reconstructions of both.

The broader impacts include the potential to better understand extreme precipitation events which exert significant social costs through both loss of life and substantial damage to property. Society manages this burden using risk mitigation strategies (e.g., infrastructure, insurance) designed for historic extreme precipitation variability that is estimated from relatively short instrumental records and may be changing under anthropogenic climate change. This project will help determine how the frequency, persistence, recurrence and geographic pattern of these impacts have varied in the past under natural climate variability. This will provide important insights into the causes of these shifts and the potential for predictability in the future. This project also provides support for graduate and post-doctoral researchers.

Outreach efforts will focus on high-level discussions with the L.A. County Flood Control District, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, and related agencies that manage extreme event risk in the region. This direct engagement will enhance the application of the research products, as well as provide guidance for their design. Innovative visualizations of research output will be made available through the Columbia Water Center for public use.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to use tree-ring records to understand the long-term nature of extreme cold-season precipitation dynamics in the western continental United States (US), especially year-to-year variability in extreme storms delivered by “atmospheric rivers.” Atmospheric rivers are wind currents that carry vast amounts of water vapor. Over the North Pacific, an atmospheric river can stretch eastward for thousands of miles and move more moisture than the Amazon River, often producing intense winter-spring downpours and flooding in the western US.

 

Near the US west coast, year-to-year variability in the frequency and location of extreme precipitation and atmospheric rivers are major contributors to the region’s water resources, but these storms are also major drivers of flood risk. Given that extreme events are inherently rare, our relatively short (~70 year) observational records leave open the possibility that we have little idea as to what these events are truly capable of. For example, was the frequency of atmospheric river and extreme precipitation events over the last 70 years normal in the context of the last millennium? What is the expected return time for a year like 1862 when repeated atmospheric river events and heavy precipitation flooded California’s Central Valley? How common are 5-year stretches with very few atmospheric rivers in California, such as 2012–2016?

 

While the annual nature of tree rings may make them ill-suited to study individual storm events, a tree-ring record may still prove useful in detecting year-to-year swings in the number (frequency) of extreme events. Further, a large network of hundreds of tree-ring records across a region may be useful in capturing the spatial signature of atmospheric river activity. For example, atmospheric rivers hitting southern California and penetrating inland from the southwest will affect the spatial pattern of soil moisture (and therefore tree-ring widths) across the western US differently than atmospheric rivers making landfall elsewhere or even at a different angle. Our work is the first to explore the potential to use tree rings to extend our understanding of regional atmospheric river activity and extreme precipitation beyond the modern observational period.

 

Thus far our work has focused largely on California, where a uniquely large proportion of cold-season precipitation is delivered by extremes. In two studies, one of southern California and one of northern California, we used a large dataset of precipitation-sensitive tree-ring records to reconstruct the annual number of atmospheric river and extreme precipitation events back to the 1400s. We found that specific spatial patterns of soil-moisture anomalies and tree-ring widths across the West do indeed correspond to variations in location and frequency of atmospheric rivers and extreme precipitation, and that nuances of the spatial patterns of tree-ring widths across the region even provide information as to the angles at which the atmospheric rivers made landfall. Our reconstructions of atmospheric river frequency in California agree well with observations (which begin around 1950) and are also corroborated by historical accounts of flooding prior to the observational record, such as California’s Great Flood in 1862. The reconstruction also shows that atmospheric river activity was highly variable over the past 600 years, with a century-long period of relatively few extreme events from the mid-1400s to mid-1500s and several years with exceptionally high frequency of northern California extreme events in the late 1500s (in northern California) and late 1800s (in southern California)that likely exceeded any single-year frequencies in the observed period. The reconstructions also indicate that the 1980s stand out as potentially the decade with the highest frequency of atmospheric rivers and extreme precipitation in 600 years in both northern and southern California.

 

While the work described above is geographically focused, it serves as a broad methodological advance and proof of concept that large networks of tree-ring records can be used to detect historical fluctuations in atmospheric river location, path of travel, and frequency. Our methods can be applied to other west-coast regions with high densities of tree-ring records such as Chile and Portugal/Spain. Our reconstructions of atmospheric river frequency for California, and future reconstructions for other regions that will be made using methods we developed, will benefit society: without multi-century reconstructions, we have a very limited understanding of the full range of variability of atmospheric river frequency and therefore whether current infrastructure and policy are appropriately designed. Long reconstructions can also be used to assess the capability of climate models to realistically simulate atmospheric river activity. We are directly engaged with government agencies such as the California Department of Water Resources and the US Army Corps of Engineers to make sure that our results, and more broadly the capability of tree-rings to reconstruct atmospheric river activity, can be used to inform infrastructure design and policy. One PhD student was also trained through participation in this project.
